titleStmt.title: Effects of Nb on deformation-induced transformation and mechanical properties of HfNbxTa0.2TiZr high entropy alloys

analytic.title: Effects of Nb on deformation-induced transformation and mechanical properties of HfNbxTa0.2TiZr high entropy alloys

biblStruct.note: Received 8 September 2020; Received in revised form 7 January 2021; Accepted 15 January 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High-entropy alloys Transformation induced plasticity Mechanical properties Twinning

div.p: Body-centered cubic (BCC) refractory HEAs which have shown interesting properties at elevated temperatures such as outstanding high-temperature strength, high oxidation and corrosion resistance, nevertheless, they are generally brittle at ambient temperature, which limits their practical uses. Application of the transformationinduced plasticity (TRIP) concept into these BCC HEAs like HfTaTiZr has confirmed to be an effective approach to addressing this critical challenge. To further reveal the underlying mechanisms and improve the overall properties, in this work, we attempted to reveal the interplay between the phase stability, strain-induced transformation and deformation in HfNbxTa0.2TiZr (x = 0, 0.15, 0.20 and 0.25) HEAs. It was found that proper addition of Nb could not only enhance the TRIP effect due to the reduced phase stability of the prior BCC phase, but also facilitate twinning in the product HCP (hexagonal close packing) phase at the late stage of deformation. As a result, the HfNb0.2Ta0.2TiZr HEA shows much enhanced mechanical properties, i.e., pronounced work hardening behavior and large uniform ductility of up to 26%, which surmounts most of refractory BCC HEAs reported previously. Our findings are important not only for understanding the deformation mechanism of the TRIP reinforced HEAs, but also for the future development of other high-performance HEAs.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Recently, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) have attracted extensive interests because of their high thermal stability and promising mechanical properties such as high hardness, oxidation and corrosion resistance and outstanding low-temperature mechanical properties [1][2][3][4][5][6][7][8]. Among which, BCC (body-centered-cubic) HEAs based on refractory elements exhibit extremely stable microstructure against temperature, which endows them great potential for high-temperature application [9,10]. However, most refractory BCC HEAs suffer from poor ductility at room temperature, impeding their practical uses [11,12].

Recently, substantial property improvement has been realized in BCC HfNbTiZr HEAs via introduction of interstitials such as oxygen to form chemical short-range ordering, successfully overcoming the socalled strength-ductility tradeoff [13]. Another effective route is to apply the transformation-induced-plasticity (TRIP) concept, as demonstrated in several BCC HEAs, i.e., Hf 27.5 Nb 5 Ta 5 Ti 35 Zr 27.5 , Hf 25 Sn 2 Ta 10- Ti 38 Zr 25 , HfTa0.5TiZr, HfTa0.4TiZr and NbTaTiZr [14][15][16][17][18][19][20][21]. It was found that the TRIP effect could greatly alleviate the stress concentration and improve the plasticity by inducing strong work-hardening capacity. For example, by tailoring the relative content of Mn and Fe in Fe 80-x Mn x- Co 10 Cr 10 (at.%) alloys, the phase transition appeared in the non-equimolar Fe 50 Mn 30 Co 10 Cr 10 alloy from metastable FCC to HCP and the TRIP effect eventually gave rise to the ultimate tensile strength of about 850 MPa with elongation of about 74% [14]. Also, Huang et al. reported that gradually reducing the content of Ta in the HfTaTiZr alloy could destabilize the BCC parent phase and then significantly improve the mechanical properties via the TRIP effect [16].

Although there have been several successful cases in improving the plasticity of brittle refractory BCC HEAs by applying the TRIP effect, the underlying mechanism responsible for the TRIP effects remains obscure and the comprehensive mechanical properties need to be further improved. It is reasonable to rationalize that the mechanical performance of these BCC HEAs is closely related to the involved transformation potency and the structural stability of the parent phase. BCC stabilizers such as Ta and Nb would strongly influence phase stability of the parent phase and then the deformation-induced martensitic transformation. Thus, it is interesting to investigate effects of these BCC stabilizers on the deformation mechanism and mechanical properties of the refractory BCC HEAs.

In this work, effects of a strong BCC stabilizer, Nb, on crystal structures, phase stability and mechanical properties of the HfNbxTa0.2TiZr (x = 0, 0.15, 0.20 and 0.25) alloys were systematically investigated. The strength-ductility tradeoff was successfully reversed in the quinary HfNb0.2Ta0.2TiZr HEA, and its overall mechanical properties were much improved as compared with those of the quaternary HfTa0.4TiZr [16]. The underlying mechanisms responsible for the outstanding mechanical properties were also carefully explored with particular emphasis on the TRIP effect and related twinning in deformation induced HCP.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: Ti, Zr, Hf, Nb and Ta with purity of 99.99 at. % were used as raw materials for preparation of alloy ingots with a nominal composition of HfNbxTa0.2TiZr (x = 0, 0.15, 0.2 and 0.25). Hereafter the alloys are referred as Nb0, Nb0.15, Nb0.2 and Nb0.25, respectively, for simplicity. The alloy ingots were prepared by arc-melting a mixture of pure metals in an argon atmosphere and re-melted at least four times to ensure homogeneity. The ingots were then quenching by drop casting into Cu mold with a dimension of 10 mm × 10 mm × 60 mm.

Phase constitution of the alloys was characterized by using X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in a scanning 2θ range of 20 /min. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with electron back-scattering diffraction (EBSD) (i.e., a Zeiss Supra55 SEM equipped with an HKL channel 5 system operated at 20 kV) was utilized to investigate microstructure of the as-cast, pre-strained and fractured specimens. Samples for the EBSD tests were firstly ground and polished down to a 2000-grit SiC paper and then further electrochemically polished in a solution containing 64% methanol, 30% butanol and 6% perchloric acid at 253 K with a direct voltage of 30 V for 20s. A transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai F30) operated at 300 kV was employed for further microstructural characterization. The TEM specimens were cut from 3 mm disks and then ground to about 50 μm in thickness, followed by twin-jet electro-polishing using a solution of CH 3 OH: CH 3 (CH 2 ) 3 OH: HClO 4 = 64:30:6 with a direct voltage of 30 V at around 243 K.

Room-temperature tensile tests were conducted using a CMT4105 universal electronic tensile machine at a strain rate of 1 × 10 -3 s -1 on dog-bone-shaped specimens with the gauge dimension of 20 × 5 × 1.5 mm 3 . Prior to deformation, the samples were polished down to a 2000grit SiC paper. For each specimen, at least 3 measurements were carried out to ensure the accuracy of the data.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Fig. 1a shows typical true stress-strain curves for the as-cast HfNbxTa0.2TiZr (x = 0, 0.15, 0.20 and 0.25) HEAs containing a different amount of Nb. An obvious change in the strength and ductility can be seen as the Nb concentration varies. Alloy Nb0.25 shows yield strength of 748 MPa, fracture strength of 843 MPa and ductility of 14.2%. With the decrease of Nb content (i.e., Nb0.2), the fracture strength and plasticity appreciably increase to 983 MPa and 31.8%, respectively. Nevertheless, the yield strength decreases to 607 MPa. With further decrease of Nb (i.e., Nb0.15), the tensile curve displays a double yielding behavior, as frequently seen in shape memory alloys [22,23]. The yield strength is reduced as low as 406 MPa, although the fracture strength is over 1000 MPa. Note that the alloy with no Nb addition shows the highest yield and fracture strength of 1206 and 1315 MPa, respectively, but with the least ductility of 4.1%. Clearly, the mechanical performance of the current HEAs was significantly affected by the Nb concentration, and a unique combination of strength and plasticity was obtained in alloy Nb0.2. Fig. 1b shows curves of the corresponding strain-hardening rate (dσ/ dε) deduced from Fig. 1a. As can be seen, Nb0 and Nb0.25 show a continuously decreasing stain-hardening rate, which indicates a dislocation-slip-dominated plastic deformation mechanism [24]. Nevertheless, alloy Nb0.2 retains a steady hardening rate until plastic instability. The strain-hardening behavior of alloy Nb0.15 can be obviously divided into three stages, i.e., continuous drop (stage I), slight increase (stage II) and a continuous decrease (stage III). More details regarding the strain-hardening rate change will be discussed later on. Fig. 1c presents the true stress and strain-hardening rate with respect to true strain, and the intersection points corresponding to the uniform strain.

div.head: The as-cast alloys
div.p: EBSD images and XRD patterns of the as-cast alloys are shown in Fig. 2. With the increase of Nb, phase constitution exhibits a transition from a nearly single HCP phase (i.e., Nb0) to dual phases of BCC and HCP (hexagonal close packed), i.e., Nb0.15 and Nb0.2. The intensity of the HCP peaks on the XRD traces continues reducing while that of the BCC peaks keep growing as the Nb content increases, suggesting that formation of the HCP phase is suppressed but that of BCC is promoted. When the Nb element increased to 7.2 at.% (i.e., Nb0.25), few amount of the HCP phase was detected from the EBSD image, and no signal of HCP was captured by XRD due to their tiny amount.

As an example, details of the dual-phase structure were carefully analyzed in alloy Nb0.2. As shown in Fig. 3a, along with the selected area diffraction (SAD) patterns, it is confirmed that the as-cast Nb0.2 alloy assumes a dual-phase structure of HCP and BCC, which is consistent with the EBSD and XRD results. The pre-existing HCP phase is thermally induced by displacive transformation during the quenching process. Furthermore, elemental partitioning of the dual-phase structure was analyzed in Nb0.2 by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 3b. Clearly, no apparent elemental segregation is observed, indicating a uniform distribution of all the elements, confirming a diffusionless martensitic transformation during solidification. Moreover, homogeneous distribution of all constituent elements suggests that both phases benefit from the same level of solid solution strengthening. Fig. 3c shows the crystallographic orientation relationship between the BCC and primary HCP phase, which was verified to be {110} BCC//{0001} HCP by the corresponding pole figures.

div.head: The deformed alloys
div.p: To analyze phase evolution during deformation, EBSD phase maps of the Nb0.2 samples pre-strained to 8%, 16% and fracture are shown in Fig. 4a1-a3, revealing the deformation-induced martensitic transformation as deformation proceeds. Clearly, as the strain increases, interwove HCP lamella plates embedded in the BCC matrix (Fig. 4a1) gradually multiplies and coarsens (Fig. 4a2), and ultimately dominate the microstructure (Fig. 4a3). Fig. 5 presents the relative volume fraction of the BCC and HCP phase as a function of applied strain. It is obvious that the fraction of HCP is gradually increased during tensile loading, indicating occurrence of the phase transformation from the metastable BCC to HCP. Fig. 4b1 andb2 show the corresponding EBSD band contrast (BC) images of Nb0.2 alloy pre-strained to 8% and 16%, respectively. It can be seen that the fraction of twins within HCP also gradually increased, as indicated by the white arrow.

In order to reveal the mechanism of the involved phase transformation, microstructure of a fractured Nb0.2 sample was carefully investigated by TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 6. After the tensile deformation, numerous parallel lath-shaped structures distributed in the matrix appeared (Fig. 6a). The SAD patterns of these areas (Fig. 6b andc) reveal that they have a HCP lattice. In addition, the SAD patterns (Fig. 6e) of the magnified lath-shaped structure interior (Fig. 6d) reveal existence of the {0111} twinning spots, which suggests the trace of twinning in the HCP phase. Fig. 7 shows SEM images of the cross-section and lateral surfaces of the fractured specimens with different Nb concentrations. As can be seen, as the Nb content is decreased, the quantity of dimples, either ellipse or equiaxed, increases but the size decreases, suggesting a more ductile deformation behavior. Moreover, extensive slip/shear bands were observed inside the grains of alloys Nb0.25, Nb0.2 and Nb0.15, but sparsely in Nb0.

div.head: Effects of Nb on the phase formation and phase stability
div.p: As a strong BCC-stabilizer, Nb plays an important role in phase formation in these HEAs. Based on the EBSD map analysis (Fig. 2), the relative volume fraction for BCC and HCP phases of all the alloys prior to deformation was estimated and the results are shown in Fig. 8. Clearly, as the Nb concentration decreases, the propensity to form BCC declines whereas that to form HCP martensite enhances upon solidification. The HEA with the highest Nb content about 7.2 at.% (i.e., Nb0.25) renders a single BCC and the formation of HCP is completely inhibited. When less Nb is added (e.g., Nb0.2), the volume fraction of BCC reduces while HCP starts to form. As the Nb content is further decreased (Nb0.15), the volume fraction of BCC is further reduced and becomes negligible in the In conventional Ti-based alloys, the stability of the BCC phase can be predicted based on the DV-Xα cluster method [25], and therefrom two electronic property parameters were defined. One is the bond order (Bo), which describes the bond strength between Ti and the alloying elements, whilst another is the metal d-orbital energy level (Md), which relates to the energy level of the d-orbitals and takes into account the atomic radius and the electronegativity of the elements [15]. For an alloy, the average values of bond order Bo and d-orbital energy levels Md are calculated as follows:
div.formula: Bo = ∑ i x i Bo i (1) Md = ∑ i x i Md i (2)
div.p: where x i is the atomic fraction of element i in the alloy, Bo i and Md i are the bond order and metal d-orbital energy level values for the element i, respectively [25].

"Alloying vectors" on a Bo-Md map, originated from the Bo and Md values of pure Ti, represent the ability of each element to stabilize either the α phase or the β phase in binary alloys [26], are shown in Fig. 9a. The alloy position moves as the alloy composition varies because a vector varies in direction and magnitude, depending on alloying elements [27,28]. Therefore, Ti-containing BCC HEAs characterized by high alloying and multi-components with BCC stabilizers (e.g., Ta and Nb) usually show higher Bo and Md values, as compared with traditional binary and ternary titanium alloys [15,28].

It should be noted that the Bo -Md standard diagram was strategically mapped for Ti-alloys [28]. Recently, it was confirmed that the Bo -Md map is also applicable for Ti-rich HEAs [15,20,21]. In our case, the HEAs containing about 30 at% Ti (i.e., 29.9 at.% for Nb0.15, 29.4at.% for Nb0.2 and 29.0at.% for Nb0.25) and could be approximately regarded as Ti-rich alloys. Therefore, we here attempt to apply this criterion to further evaluate the phase stability of the current HEAs, as Obviously, reduction of Nb decreases Bo but increases Md, moving the alloy position closer to the M s = RT line. This trend clearly reveals that decrease of Nb in the current HEAs deteriorates the stability of BCC but promotes stress-induced martensitic transformation, which is consistent with our experimental observations. However, considering the fact that the unique characteristics of HEAs are very different from those of Ti-based alloy, such as the high distorted lattice and sluggish diffusion effect in HEAs, martensitic transformation processes in composition-complex HEAs are more sluggish, as with that in simple titanium alloys even both located at a similar distance to the β/α phase boundary in the diagram [20]. In addition, more and more studies reveal that the arrangement of atoms in HEAs is not an ideal disordered state and usually results in short-range ordering (SRO) structures during solidification [13,31], which could also have some effects on the phase stability and deformation process.

To verify the above observation, we have estimated fraction of the BCC and HCP phase in the as-cast and fractured samples, as shown in Table 1. With the decrease of Nb, it is obvious that the fraction of BCC phase in the as-cast samples is decreased, but interestingly, the percentage of the BCC phase transformed to HCP during deformation is increased, indicating that reduction of Nb destabilize the BCC but promotes the martensitic transformation, which is consistent with the trend in the Bo-Md diagram (Fig. 9b).

To sum up, it seems that Bo and Md parameters can reflect relative phase stability in the current HEA system, and adjusting the Nb concentration is also a reliable yet effective approach to controlling the relative phase stability and thus the deformation mechanism in the present HEAs.

div.head: Effects of Nb on the deformation behavior
div.p: As shown in Fig. 1, mechanical properties such as work hardening behavior and uniform strain of the current HEAs are varied significantly with the Nb content. The HEA containing the highest amount of Nb (i.e., Nb0.25) has a stable BCC lattice structure, and no stress-induced transformation occurred. The corresponding work-hardening rate (Fig. 1b) shows a continuously decreasing trend, which is attributed to dynamic recovery and indicates a dislocation-slip-dominated plastic deformation mechanism [24]. Different from other typical brittle BCC HEAs [11,12], Nb0.25 exhibits relatively ductile deformation behavior with a fracture strain of 14.2%, which might be interpreted from the point of the VEC (valence electron concentration) criterion proposed previously [32], i.e., the VEC of Nb0.25 is 4.13, less than the upper limit for ductile HEAs (i.e., 4.4). It is to note that Nb0.25 shows higher yield strength but lower fracture strength and ductility than those of Nb0.2 and Nb0.15 with dual phases, which is due to its stable BCC phase against the phase transformation. Due to the larger amount of Nb, which is a strong BCC stabilizer, the potency of deformation-induced phase transformation is obviously demoted, ad consequently, the work hardening capacity is reduced, thus leading to higher yield strength but low fracture strength and ultimate ductility.

With the decrease of the Nb concentration (i.e., Nb0.2), a dual-phase structure consisting of BCC and HCP was formed. Based on the earlier discussion, the BCC stability in this alloy is destabilized, which can also be reflected by the reduced yield strength (607 MPa). With the increase of strain, the deformation induced transformation from BCC to HCP remains a prevailing deformation mechanism throughout the whole plastic deformation process, leading to a relatively small fraction of retained BCC phase as shown in Fig. 5. The phase transformation process leads to the strong work hardening due to a dynamic strain-stress partitioning effect [33].

It is interesting to point out that twinning inside the product HCP phase also increases with the strain, as indicated by the white arrow in Fig. 4 b1-b2. Compared with the similar HfTa0.5TiZr HEA that we reported previously, addition of Nb seemingly promotes twining in the newly formed HCP, which could likely be attributed to a decreased stacking fault energy (SFE). It was argued that the VEC value could be used as the key descriptor to evaluate the SFE, and a smaller VEC often indicates a lower SFE [34,35]. The calculations show that the Nb0.2 has a VEC value of 4.117, which is smaller that of Ta0.5HfZrTi (i. e., 4.143) [16]. Moreover, the axial ratio of c/a (a is the basal lattice axis and c is the longitudinal axis) in HCP is also associated with the SFE, and a higher c/a ratio often corresponds to the a lower SFE [36]. The c/a of Nb0.2 is 1.601 (see Table 2 for detailed values), higher than that of HfTa0.5TiZr (i.e., 1.520) [16], further indicating a lower SFE after alloying with Nb. As such, it is rationalized that the addition of Nb reduces the SFE in newly formed HCP, thus promoting twinning in the late stage of deformation and then giving rise to strain hardening through the dynamic Hall-Petch effect, i.e., the interface density increases constantly through the continuously formed twins [14,37]. Therefore, both facilitated phase transformation and twinning contribute to the sustained and steady work hardening rate (Fig. 1b), which postpones the onset of necking instability and homogenized the plastic flow, as shown in Fig. 7b andf. Compared with HfTa0.5TiZr, the fracture strength (983 MPa) and plasticity (31.8%) of Nb0.2 are further increased due to the addition of Nb.

When the Nb content is further decreased (i.e., Nb0.15), formation of the HCP is facilitated at the expense of BCC during solidification (Fig. 2). From Fig. 1b, it is clear that the strain hardening rate of this HEA can be divided into three stages; stage I has a classical decrease which was observed in all the HEAs corresponding to the conventional elastic to plastic transition and dislocation-slip-dominated plastic deformation [16]. Note that the BCC stability in this HEA is further reduced, resulting in a low yield strength (406 MPa) and a high phase transformation ratio of BCC (~100%). As a result, most of the strain at the early stage of plastic deformation is accommodated by the TRIP effect, leading to an increasing work hardening rate up to ε ≈ 6% in the stage II (Fig. 1b). As the strain increases, the hardening effect resulted from phase transformation tends to saturate and deformation is again dominated by dislocation slip, which yields a gradual decrease trend in the stage III. It has been suggested that plastic strain is preferentially accommodated inside the deformation induced HCP martensite [18], rather than in the original HCP formed during cooling. As shown in Fig. 1b, the work hardening rate in the latter part of stage III shows a slow decline behavior until zero, rendering the fracture strength and plasticity to 1003 MPa and 25.8%, respectively. This observation suggests superior plastic deformation capacity of the deformation induced HCP in Nb0.15, which is actually confirmed by dense slip bands on the lateral surface (Fig. 7g), and small and dense dimples on the fracture surface (Fig. 7c). Although the TRIP effect of Nb0.15 is more obvious as compared with Nb0.2 alloy (Fig. 1b), its performance is not the best. In this particular alloy, the fraction of the prior BCC phase is reduced but the potency of the martensitic transformation is excessively enhanced. As a result, the work hardening rate quickly reaches the maximum, i.e., at early deformation stage, and then quickly exhausted due to the limited parent BCC phase, resulting in a reduced tensile strength and plasticity.

Finally, Nb0 alloy with no Nb addition consists of a single stable HCP phase. It has been reported that the thermally induced HCP in FCC HEAs is harder and less deformable [18]. Therefore, due to the lack of additional deformation mechanism other than dislocation slips and weak plastic deformation capacity, the work-hardening rate curve of this HEA shows a sharp decrease trend (Fig. 1b), similarly to that of TiZrHfAlNb [38]. Hence, a high yield strength (≈1206 MPa) and fracture strength (≈1315 MPa) but very limited plasticity (≈4.1%) were obtained, as shown in Fig. 1a. Consequently, the corresponding fracture surface exhibits pronounced intergranular and trans-granular mixed fracture mode while lateral surface shows sparse slip bands (Fig. 7d andh), indicating a less ductile deformation behavior.

The uniform elongation indicates the degree that work hardening counteracts a reducing cross sectional area during tensile straining, which marks the onset of diffuse necking and has often been taken as guide for the extent of useful stretching [39]. However, BCC HEAs for which plasticity is exclusively driven by dislocation glide and present a very low work hardening rate, bringing about rapid strain localization and low uniform ductility levels [40]. Here, the newly designed Nb0.2 HEA, benefitting from not only the TRIP effect but also the twinning within the deformation induced HCP, demonstrates outstanding uniform strain of up to 26% (see Fig. 1c), which surmounts most of other BCC HEAs [15,40]. It is worth noting that, the phenomenon about the beneficial effect of deformation twinning on the uniform elongation also has been reported in HCP Mg and its alloys [39].

As discussed above, it is clear that BCC metastability strongly depends on the Nb content and influences the preferential deformation modes. Careful tuning stability of the prior BCC phase and the deformation capacity of the product HCP phases opens up new opportunities to investigate the TRIP effects and its link with the level of work hardenability in relevant HEAs [41,42]. In the future, it would be interesting to compare effects of Nb with those of other BCC-stabilizing elements (e. g., Mo, V and Ta) and then establish alloying principles for further optimizing the performance of these refractory HEAs.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In conclusion, this work investigated effects of the BCC-stabilizer Nb on the phase constitution, phase stability, work hardening and mechanical properties of the HfNbxTa0.2TiZr HEAs. The results revealed that the proportion and stability of prior BCC and phase transformation ratio of BCC during deformation are strongly dependent on the amount of Nb. Decreasing the Nb content reduces the BCC phase stability and promotes the martensitic transformation from BCC to HCP upon loading. Moreover, additional mechanical twinning in the product HCP phase was also activated due probably to the lower SFE resulted from the Nb addition, giving rise to an enhanced sustained strain hardening rate and thus a superior combination of strength (983 MPa) and uniform ductility (>26%), which surmounts the level of most BCC refractory HEAs reported previously. This work provides a useful approach to further enhancing the comprehensive properties of refractory BCC HEAs; careful tuning the stability of prior BCC phase and deformation capacity of product HCP phase is effective in overcoming diffusive necking and obtaining large uniform ductility.

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Volume fraction of the BCC and HCP phase in the as-cast and fractured HEAs, along with the percentage of the BCC phase transformed during deformation obtained by EBSD phase mapping.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. (a) Room temperature tensile mechanical properties of the Nbx alloys, (b) the corresponding strain-hardening rate curves and (c) curves of true stress/work hardening rate against true strain. The data after the cross-over points are not shown.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. Phase constitutions and fractions (red represents HCP while blue indicates BCC) for the as-cast HfNbxTa0.2TiZr HEA as a function of the Nb content. The spectra above the microstructure images show the corresponding X-ray diffraction traces. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Microstructure of the as-cast Nb0.2 HEA. (a) TEM bright-field images of the co-existed BCC and HCP phase, (b) Electronic diffraction spectroscopy (EDS) maps of the two phase regions in Nb0.2 HEA showing that all elements are uniformly distributed, and (c) Pole figures showing the crystallographic orientation for the {110}BCC and the {0001}HCP in alloy Nb0.2.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. EBSD images of the Nb0.2 HEA pre-strained to (a1) 8%, (a2)16% and (a3) failure, and EBSD band contrast images of Nb0.2 alloy pre-strained to (b1) 8% and (b2) 16%.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. The volume fraction of BCC and HCP phase as a function of applied strain in Nb0.2 HEAs.

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. (a~d): SEM images of the fractured Nb0.25, Nb0.2, Nb0.15 and Nb0 HEAs after the tensile deformation, and (e ~ h) the corresponding fracture lateral surfaces.

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. Volume fraction of the BCC and HCP phase as a function of Nb content in the as-cast samples.

figure.head: Fig. 9 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 9. (a) Alloying vectors of elements M in Ti drawn on the Bo-Md diagram for various Ti-M binary alloys. Each vector starts at the position of pure Ti and ends at the position of Ti-10 at.% M alloy [29]. (b) Bo-Md diagram extrapolated to the high-Bo-high-Md domain [30]. The position of the current HEAs locates in the upper right corner.

figure.head: Table 2
figure.figDesc: Lattice constants of the constituent phases in the four alloys derived from the XRD results.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
